poem:
Title: "On Aid and Aegis"

In finest halls, the whispers flutter,
rising on partisan plume.
An aid bill passes, a surprise,
with opposition in full bloom.
Israel bears the weight of desire,
and Ukraine wears the gloom.
We pluck the threads of diplomacy,
amid the Senate's echoes in backroom.
Each word weighed and measured,
each vote, a loom.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Schumer says Senate should ‘finish the job’ with foreign aid vote as Sanders seeks to strip funding for Israel weapons – live 4.55pm BST That the House passed the foreign aid bill is somewhat of a surprise. Anti-Ukraine sentiment is rife and growing among the Republicans who hold a slim majority in that chamber, and speaker Mike Johnson’s decision to put the foreign aid bill up for a vote – and passing it with the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
